https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/94001/ : SUCCESS
What is the proposed standardization though... seems like this proposal is "do things the AMD way in an AMD repository"?
The application uses a standard crashdump record format based on the UEFI-defined Common Platform Error Record (CPER) layout.

Why are we proposing OEM Redfish interfaces?  Has this been proposed to the Redfish Forum already?

I suspect you haven't read this: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/a88942019fdd3d8fc366999f7c178f3e1c18b2fe/OEM_SCHEMAS.md#L1

The OEM Redfish interface will be removed from the document.
We will propose the new OEM Redfish interface to the Redfish Forum and will update this document in the future once the proposal is made.

This implies there can only be one crashdump application on a single BMC.  There are multi-host BMCs that use an SMC* to abstract much of the processor specifics away.  It is possible to have different processor vendors installed in a single chassis.

(*) Satellite management controller.

Patrick,
   In the multi host systems, with different processor configuration, Satelite BMC is only going to manage host, with same family right?  In this case AMD RAS application service , can have logic to run this application only for AMD family hosted host. is this going to slove this? Or are you refering to additional note to handle this use use?
I'm suggesting the service name needs to be more unique.
Do you have any suggestions for the service name?
Maybe com.amd.Crashdump?  Hard to know without knowing what the service is providing.  If it ends up being AMD processor-specific, it should probably be com.amd and not xyz.openbmc_project.
Thanks for the suggestion. Will change the service name to com.amd.Crashdump and send the updated document for review.

There was a lot of feedback given on this topic on the ML and Github issue before.  Primarily, the question was asked as to why this can't be integrated into phosphor-debug-collector.  I believe IBM has some code for doing that for their systems, right?

This section needs a lot more depth before we can move forward.

High level design direction followed here is aligned to the proposed design in the hw-fault-monitor design document.
https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/docs/designs/hw-fault-monitor.md?r=f4febd00.
The new Repository is used to host the AMD processor specific applications for monitoring and capturing AMD processor specific register using APML protocols.  And remaining flow is same as mentioned in the  hw-fault monitor design document.

Existing IBM Host specific dump infrastructure is also using similar approach for managing POWER processor specific applications, like openpower-hw-diags for monitoring errors and openpower-debug-collector with the help of other openpower hosted repo's to capture the processor specific chipset register information. 
As discussed earlier PDC is mainly for managing debug data and providing required interface to external users , not for Hosting processor specific error monitoring and data collection using host centric mechanisms.

Abinya will be adding more details here on the pros/cons of using existing repository for this use case

Neither of you meet the requirements listed under this document to be the initial maintainers.  We'll need someone from the TOF (or otherwise qualified) to be mentor maintainers to start with.

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/a8fff53a66656f884632322841d697c89bdba871/community-membership.md?plain=1#L183

Totally fine, if someone else wants to maintain this. However, since it involves AMD specific registers and AMD specific interrupt routines, I would like to propose Abinaya as a potential maintainer so that she can learn and develop into full fledged maintainer as this won't impact any other platforms. For this, need help from one of TOF to mentor Abinaya to maintain.

P.S: I have been the maintainer of meta-amd for few years now.
"Platform Maintainer | Review and maintain contributions to a single platform | History of testing and ownership of a given single platform."

> Abinaya as a potential maintainer so that she can learn and develop into full fledged maintainer as this won't impact any other platforms

Yes, that is the purpose of this mentoring.  Domain knowledge is expected to be with the AMD side.  Mentor is suppose to coach early submitter on project expectations to keep the quality bar at expected levels.

It is impossible for us to give the keys to someone to be a maintainer without having already contributed code to the project.  They have absolutely no experience with the expectations for the project as a whole.
Agreed. We would like to propose Jayanth Othayoth to be the maintainer of the repo.

Unit tests planned?  Any integration tests written in Robot?

What you are describing here is "test driving" and not "testing".  There is no way for anyone to recreate and/or re-verify your efforts when making code changes, which puts us into a really bad spot.

Unit testing code will be supported as OpenBMC standards.
There is no significant impact expected with regards CI testing.
Abinaya will be adding details on this here.
Hi Abinaya, I've made several comments. Some are to do with markdown and layout, but others are more pressing concerns with the design or presentation of the design details.
Hi Andrew. Thanks for the detailed review. We will work on the review comments and get back with the updated document.

The glossary makes reference to the UEFI spec and APML (which presumably has a specification as well). However, there's currently no link to the referenced document here in the `Background and References` section. Can you please fix that?
As per the Problem Description, shouldn't the requirement be related to defining a platform agnostic way to collect crashdump data rather than just defining a way to do so for AMD processors?

As mentioned, the mechanism to monitor and collect crashdump data via APML interface is specific to AMD processors and cannot be used on other platforms. But packaging the crashdump record is done in a standardized way by following the CPER format.

Can you please make this a proper markdown link? E.g.

```
...
2. Provide a mechanism to format crash data as per [the UEFI specification][uefi-specification-2.10]

[uefi-specification-2.10]: https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/
...
```
Shouldn't this interface be platform agnostic too?

Many of the properties exposed in the configuration interface are also specific to AMD error monitoring mechanism. So the preference is to have an AMD processor-specific interface. Please let us know if there is any suggestion to use an existing platform-agnostic interface.
Is BMC RAS an existing application or a new one being proposed?
This is a new application proposed.

I strongly prefer you don't try to over-generalise at this point. Just write this as if you're solving your specific problem, i.e. in the context of AMD processors inspected via APML. Adding parentheses everywhere to specify the AMD case is what I don't want to see.

Once we get others who have crash-dump concerns reviewing this document we can work on consensus on how to generalise it. At that point we can discuss other implementations like PECI, FSI, etc.
This seems overly specific. Why is it necessary to specify the path here?
Removed the path specified in the document as the D-Bus interface is used to list/delete/download the file.
Whats the existing Redfish interface for retrieving the crashdump? If there is one is it sufficient enough to support the flow and expose the required info?
The existing redfish interface /redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/FaultLog is used to retrieve the crashdump files. Updated the document with the info.

Generally the OpenBMC data model (for better or worse) is to represent objects on DBus and not so much on the filesystem. Why have we opted for the filesystem here?

Are the bmcweb maintainers on-board with this proposal?

How does it interact with phosphor-debug-collector?

The proposal uses the D-Bus to perform any operation on the CPER files. Hence removed the filepath. Also, plese find the updated document which discusses the changes needed in phosphor-debug-collector and bmcweb.

This goes into a lot of detail about the mechanics of collecting the crashdump at the APML library level, but it doesn't do much at all to illustrate the OpenBMC specific pieces that you're proposing here.

I still haven't internalised how the dbus interfaces and various repositories interact in the proposal. I would like to see a diagram of those interactions if we are to have a diagram (or, in addition to this diagram).

markdown links tend to misbehave across line-breaks. For instance, you can see that the link is not correctly displayed in the rendered document here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/f2722cdfbf62dfbb4bffe25d5db16ab2fe525b68/designs/oem/amd/amd-bmc-ras.md#amd-bmc-ras-application-high-level-architectural-diagram

Please fix the link.
Would this involve any change to DBus interface for phosphor-debug-collector? If yes, can you please share the proposed change PR?
Please find the D-Bus intrface change in the updated document.
Is there a proposed interface change for this? If yes, can you please share it?

To get an early review from the community, a Gerrit request was raised for the com.amd.Crashdump.Configuration dbus interface. Please check the link https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/65683

I think some of the queries above should drive expansion of this section. This section is meant to compel the reader that your proposed design is the best design. That means addressing all the alternative design points throughout and arguing against them. For instance, the discussion about the use of `/var/lib/bmc-ras` instead of exploiting DBus representations.
If you've removed `/var/lib/bmc-ras` as a proposal, the fact that you removed it should go in this section (you removed it because it was a worse alternative, right?).
The initial CPER file will be stored in a temporary path, and as part of Dump creation, file will be moved to Dump supported format /var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/faultlog/<dump id>/CPER_FILE.

Please understand that any other approach than what's in the primary proposal is an "alternative", and we're asking that you _write down_ these alternatives. Writing down the alternatives allows us to establish _how thorough_ you've been with you design, and it is a mechanism to stop people from asking "What about ...", because you've already written down the answer.

Please add these alternative design considerations to the document.

We’ve considered using the host-power-monitor (tailored for x86) and openpower-hw-diags (for power systems) for fault monitoring. However, given their strong ties to specific platforms and the fact that AMD employs a distinct interface for its data collection mechanism, we’ve decided to host the application in a separate repository. I’ve elaborated on this in the alternatives section. Is there any additional info you are looking for? Can you please guide us?

I was talking about your `/var/lib/bmc-ras` design point that you've since moved away from. Why did you move away from it? Can you please write that down?

The paragraph above covers the considerations for `host-error-monitor` and `openpower-hw-diags`. My comment wasn't regarding that paragraph. Rather, I added the comment at the bottom of the `Alternatives Considered` section.
Thanks for the clarification. Will send the updated document addressing this review comment.
Hi Abinaya. I've made some further comments.

I'd prefer we don't pass file paths over D-Bus. Experience suggests this both clumsy and difficult to get right wrt race conditions. Instead, pass a file descriptor to the opened file. 

But, it looks like the interface probably needs fixing 😞

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Dump/Create.interface.yaml#L67
Why is the text all in caps? I'd prefer it isn't.
I'm surprised we need a new type for host dumps. What is being used by openpower-debug-collector?

AMD is using the existing xyz based interface. https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Dump/Entry/FaultLog.interface.yaml#L27 .
ODC definitions are more POWER specific.
Made a comment above about this.
If it gets accepted by the redfish forum it won't be OEM...
I'm giving this a +1 as it seems to be heading in roughly the right direction.
Design looks more cleaner now, Aligning to DMTF Schema and utilizing existing way of debug data collection using PDC/BMCWeb to manage dumps.
Hi Abinaya, I've left a bunch of comments but almost all are minor formatting issues that should improve the readability of the document.

This attempt at a link doesn't work. It renders like:

> The Common Platform Error Record (CPER),as outlined in [the UEFI specification] [uefi-specification-2.10]: https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/ , contains vendor specific informations dumped to the file along with the crashdata collected.

You can see it here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/901ed69ca0cf35a698fe080f948897e6b15f6dfe/designs/oem/amd/amd-bmc-ras.md#background-and-references
I have added the link withn the paranthesis. The link is accessible

Your use of markdown syntax remains broken. What you have renders like this:

> The Common Platform Error Record (CPER),as outlined in [the UEFI specification] [uefi-specification-2.10]:(https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/) , ...

You need to rewrite it like this:

```
The Common Platform Error Record (CPER), as outlined in [the UEFI specification](https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/), ...
```

so it then renders like this:

> The Common Platform Error Record (CPER), as outlined in [the UEFI specification](https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/), ...
I have added the link withn the paranthesis. The link is accessible

You can't split links across lines because the markdown rendering will insert a space between the specifications of the link title and URL.

Please read through https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/refs/changes/40/68440/15/designs/oem/amd/amd-bmc-ras.md#high-level-architectural-flow where you can see it render like this:

> The proposal focuses on re-using the existing [phosphor-debug-collector] (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector) to host

You need to rewrite it like this:

```
The proposal focuses on re-using the existing [phosphor-debug-collector][] to host ...

[phosphor-debug-collector]: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector
```

So it renders like this:

> The proposal focuses on re-using the existing [phosphor-debug-collector][] to host ...
>
> [phosphor-debug-collector]: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector
Please surround with backticks to make it stand out in the text.
If you're submitting a proposal to the Redfish forum, doesn't that mean it won't be OEM?
Acknowledged. This should not be a OEM redfish interface when proposed to the Redfish forum.
Please add a space before the opening parenthesis

Hi Abinaya. Please try to preview your markdown syntax to make sure it's all sensible. The links I commented on previously still don't render correctly in PS15. I've made comments that try to clarify what you need to do.
Hi Andrew. Thanks for the clarification. I will update the document and resend for review.

Please review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/71577

I believe that implements this subset of this requirement, and this doc can just be changed to pull in the common library.

Is there any use case to decode the CPER records inside the BMC ?
With the AMD direction , decoding of the CPER records will be done outside of BMC by a python script and not part of the amd-ras module.
Thanks for pointing it out. We will use libcper common library for generating the CPER records going forward.
Can you please include the gerrit link for the Dbus interface changes in the design or add it to the description as related PRs?

@Abinaya/@Jayanth, If the crashdump needs to be a user initiated action via BMCWeb how would that be handled as AMD RAS is a daemon of its own. How ould BMCWeb, phosphor-debug-collector and AMD RAS daemon interaction work in that scenarios?

I'm not sure how much we really need to hold this up any further;  It's close enough, and so long as we get responses to the open things before code starts getting pushed, and code gets pushed in a reasonable manner (not just a single dump from https://github.com/AMDESE/amd-bmc-ras) I think I'm ok with going forward.

My asks in the future:
1. LibCPER is a common library that we should use for CPER decoding going forward.  I believe it already supports some subset of AMDs messages, so we should keep that as a common cper component.  If AMD folks want to own the AMD portion of the decode, please add yourself as reviewers going forward.
2. I would like to see CPER storage somewhat standardized such that (similar to IPMI) we're just plugging in new CPER sources (APML, ARM SSIF, etc) rather than writing a new application every time.  This is outside of what this document is suggesting, but there's enough folks working on CPER at the moment, that this seems like a worthwhile goal.
Sorry for the late response. We are still looking some of the open items here and update soon.
This reads like a different design, and doesn't really go into details.  What parameters?

We have a bunch of user configuration paramaters that has a default set of values during compile time but will be altered by the user during runtime. 
A D-Bus interface gerrit review request is raised to serve this purpose. 
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/69972
Removing it for the initial design

What you've described here is essentially what https://github.com/openbmc/bios-bmc-smm-error-logger does.  Can this be included in the background as to why this application won't meet this requirement?

https://github.com/openbmc/bios-bmc-smm-error-logger/blob/1a64356f6dc40bfbc76594a51df1ec3f32bbbd69/include/dbus/file_notifier.hpp#L18
Abhinya will be updating details in alternatve considered section.
Not enough detail. "BMC" doesn't really describe the software that actually does this operation.
Are you looking for the similar details documented at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/68440/19/designs/oem/amd/amd-bmc-ras.md#102 ?
This is the first mention in the design of "BMC policy configuration".  Is this runtime or compile time?  What stores the config?

We have a bunch of user configuration paramaters that has a default set of values during compile time but will be altered by the user during runtime.
A D-Bus interface gerrit review request is raised to serve this purpose.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/69972
CPER is a binary format, and has many options for how storage works.  Can we get a little details here?

We are following the specification https://uefi.org/specs/UEFI/2.10/Apx_N_Common_Platform_Error_Record.html to create the CPER record. The file will be in hex format. Can you please additional information on the requirement ?
This reads like a requirement.  Move to requirements section.  Is N one of the configurable things?
?  This makes it sound like this review isn't really ready to approve?
@Abinaya Can this feature be added as a design extension as a separate patch? For now wouldn't it be better to supply the defaults via a platform config json file?

+1.
To get early input from OpenBMC team Abinya already initiated d-bus review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/69972/4/yaml/com/amd/RAS/Configuration.interface.yaml related to this . Please review this.
Thanks @Jagpal for the suggestion. We are removing the redfish configuration interface and will supply the defaults via a platform config json file for the initial design

I would be good if we could point out why https://github.com/openbmc/bios-bmc-smm-error-logger is system specific?  To my understanding, it reads from a PCIe sysfs interface in a very similar way APML does.  I can understand that it might be reasonable to keep them separate, and that the "SMM" in the name is poorly defined, but to my understanding that repo isn't processor specific.

Also, as far as I know AMD processors are "X86" as well, so maybe we should call out Intel/Power?
Ack, Abinya please add why bios-bmc-smm-error not considered. Most of the point you lareadya dded here , but it will be good to add this point also.
I'm not sure how using CPER or not changes the security impact
Jayanth shows that he's in emeritus status, where his contributions as of late haven't met the minimum bar for a contributor.  Is this a mistake in our scoring?

Ed, My code contribution was low last few months, due to job change. Still i maintains  phosphor-debug-collector and phosphor-certificate-manager and actively contributing reviews in this area. We are committed to continue focus on upstream activities/contributions, and this is one of our initiative to get AMD RAS upstream.
